19.text: Christmas University Challenge. Asking the questions, Jeremy Paxman.

29.text: Hello. Tis the season to be jolly,

31.text: but despite that, 14 groups of distinguished alumni have opted

35.text: to spend time answering questions instead of guzzling mince pies.

39.text: Now only the best two of those teams remain and,

42.text: in a little under half an hour, one of them

45.text: will have earned the right to call themselves series champions

48.text: and to enjoy the victor's glass of eggnog in the green room afterwards.

52.text: Now the team from the University of Hull beat Newcastle University

56.text: in round one and Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford, in the semifinals,

59.text: on which occasion they shone on seaside resorts,

63.text: St Bartholomew and the land borders of Slovenia.

66.text: They're represented again by two writers, an actor,

72.text: Hello, I'm Rosie Millard. I read English and drama at Hull.

78.text: I'm a journalist and I'm chair of the Hull City Of Culture 2017.

82.text: Hello, my name is Malcolm Sinclair.

84.text: I graduated in 1972 in drama and theology.

88.text: I'm president of Equity trade union and I'm an actor.

92.text:
- And this is their captain. 
- Hello, I'm Dame Jenni Murray.

95.text: I graduated in 1972 in French and drama

99.text: and I present Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4.

105.text: I graduated from Hull in '84 with a maths degree.

108.text: I was a pop star for a while, but now I'm a children's author,

111.text: a travel writer and I make a mean cup of tea.

119.text: The team from Trinity Hall, Cambridge,

121.text: defeated Balliol College, Oxford, in round one

123.text: and the University of Edinburgh in round two.

126.text: They delivered their answers with the same degree of aplomb,

129.text: regardless of whether they were completely wrong,

131.text: as they were on the okapi and its predators, or right,

134.text: as they frequently were on subjects

136.text: ranging from Dido, Queen of Carthage, to Joe Orton.

140.text: Their team comprises two athletes, a novelist and critic, and an actor.

147.text: Hello, I'm Tom James. I graduated in engineering in 2007.

151.text: I used to be an oarsman for the Great British rowing team

153.text: and now am a management consultant.

157.text: I'm Emma Pooley. I graduated in 2005 in engineering.

160.text: I'm a retired professional cyclist, now a professional triathlete.

166.text: I graduated in 1976 in English and I'm a novelist and critic.

172.text: I graduated in Anglo-Saxon, Norse and Celtic in 1999 and I'm now an actor.

182.text: Right, it's the final, so let's not waste any time

185.text: and crack on with a first starter for ten.

194.text: are variations of which Swiss dish, the Latin meaning half...

199.text:
- Fondue. 
- Fondue is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

204.text: So you get the first set of bonuses, Trinity Hall. They're on bridges.

213.text: in Venice connects the Doge's Palace to the Prigioni Nuove or New Prison?

219.text:
- Bridge of Sighs? 
- It's the only bridge I know in Venice.

239.text: It's noted for its roofed passageway flanked by rows of shops.

243.text:
- Ponte Vecchio. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

246.text: What two-word English term is used in Japan to refer

252.text: have moved a number of public holidays

260.text:
- whose members include Mark Berry and... 
- BUZZER

264.text:
- Happy Mondays? 
- Happy Mondays is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

286.text:
- OK. 
- So the dynasty. Any idea of the dynasty? 
- Manchukuo? 
- He was the last.

290.text:
- The Peter O'Toole film by Bertolucci, The Last Emperor. 
- Sorry.

306.text:
- - There was Augustulus... - Constantine. 
- Two names.

319.text:
- Romulus Augustulus. 
- Correct, yes, or Romulus Augustus.

330.text: 1895, so it would have been the last king...

338.text: She wouldn't have been emperor anyway.

341.text:
- George V or VI? 
- No, George VI.

342.text:
- Confident? 
- Still alive, because he died in '52.

346.text: - Was Victoria not... - She was the first empress.

349.text:
- George VI. 
- Correct, yes. Right, ten points for this.

357.text: television service broadcast by the BBC?

362.text: the publication of Gone With The Wind,

393.text:
- Do you want Rosalind? Do you fancy Rosalind? 
- Yeah.

407.text:
- Claudio.

415.text: wrongly believes his old childhood friend to be the infant's father?

424.text: with ten countries highlighted and ranked.

430.text: to what specific sporting achievement of 2014

- No, we got skiing medals.

517.text:
- I think cross-country skiing. 
- I think Germany's always... Yep.

- Look at the 23. That seems important.

532.text: Well, they've got the 23, so let's go with that.

537.text:

540.text:
- Oh, blimey. OK. 
- Finally, this, please.

- Oh, skeleton?

554.text:
- Skeleton luge. 
- No, it's curling. 
- Curses! 
- Sorry.

559.text: Fingers on the buzzers all of you, please.

565.text: include a word meaning defensive armour for the body,

569.text: the name of a South American capital, and the first name

587.text: So a first set of bonuses for you.

593.text: which two punctuation marks form the interrobang,

597.text: invented in 1962 to punctuate a question asked in an excited manner?

615.text: Exclamation mark and question mark together.

618.text:
- A question mark and an exclamation mark together.

640.text: is shared by a punctuation mark proposed in 2006,

644.text: comprising a full stop followed by a tilde and denoting sarcasm?

- I'll try griffin. 
- Walrus. 
- Griffin or a walrus?

671.text:
- A griffin. 
- No, it's a snark. 
- Ah! 
- Of course.

702.text: of individual alpha particles and other ionising radiation?

- Kinetic energy?

739.text: Each is equivalent to one Joule per kilogram.

748.text: Named after a scientist. British physicist.

752.text: I don't know any British physicists.

758.text: Come on, let's have it, please.

763.text: No, they're Gray units. Ten points for this.

856.text: Er... It's not a million miles away. It's not far from Sheffield.

949.text: 'The world and we have passed the midway point

982.text: 'ask what you can do for your country.'
